equally distributed in branching and tabulate acroporas. A li

Reef tops were characteristically more bleached. The very common, monopolising  table coral, Acropora hyacinthus, remained largely unaffected in depths greater than a couple of metres.  This species was one of the first to go in Fiji's

properties.COUNTRY: Australia - Torres Strait & Great Barrier Reef
properties.NOTES:
Acropora colonies (staghorn corals) are mainly affected although there is a general whitening of most species. 
The corals showing the next greatest effect are the bushy species such as Pocillopora, Stylophora and Seriatopora.(Hoegh-Guldberg, O. et al.)
properties.MORTALITY: mortality running at around 20%
properties.RB_SOURCE:
Hoegh-Guldberg, O., R. Johnstone and  S. Dove 
http://www.marine.uq.edu.au/news/GBR-2002/index.htm and
Hoegh-Guldberg, O and A. Salih 
NOAA Bleaching Report Page http://orbit-net.nesdis.noaa.gov/orad/sub/bleaching_report_index.html

properties.LOCATION: Kanton and Orona, Phoenix Island, Kiribati.
properties.NOTES:
Corals affected were principally Acropora spp. and
Echinopora,with less than 5-10% of colonies affected in some patches.  It looked more like 'normal' paling of lagoon corals
due to turbidity or lack of circulation.

properties.COUNTRY: Australia - Torres Strait & Great Barrier Reef
properties.NOTES:
70% bleached at the deep area, 82% bleached at the shallow area
Millepora and Pocilloporid severly affected. Acropora palifera highly susceptable. Tabular and areborescent Acropora high mortality. Montipora bimodal reponse.
Astreopora not severe
properties.MORTALITY: 2% dead at the deeper area and 16% at the shallower area
properties.RB_SOURCE:
Marshall, P.A. and A.H. Baird, 2000  
Bleaching of corals on the Great Barrier Reef: differential susceptibilities among taxa. Coral Reefs 19(2):155-163

properties.NOTES:
Bleaching was observed at 2 shallow bays  with 50-100% coral affected.
Depth of bleaching was down to 5m, with majority in the top 2-3m
properties.RB_SOURCE: Srinivasan, M. 2000. Coral Bleaching And Climate Change.  In Munday P.L. (Ed.) The Status Of Coral Reefs In Papua New Guinea. Global Coral Reef Monitoring Network (GCRMN).

properties.LOCATION: Tamane Puli Marine Reserve, Kimbe Bay
properties.NOTES: Trend of increased bleaching in deeper water, as observed by divers.  20m, bleached corals were 10-13% of the total substratum cover.  At 10m, the bleached corals ranged from approximately 1-10% of the total substratum cover
properties.RB_SOURCE: Srinivasan, M. 2000. Coral Bleaching And Climate Change.  In Munday P.L. (Ed.) The Status Of Coral Reefs In Papua New Guinea. Global Coral Reef Monitoring Network (GCRMN).

properties.NOTES:

1999
properties.RB_SOURCE: Srinivasan, M. 2000. Coral Bleaching And Climate Change.  In Munday P.L. (Ed.) The Status Of Coral Reefs In Papua New Guinea. Global Coral Reef Monitoring Network (GCRMN).

properties.NOTES:
Extensive bleaching of the top 8 to10 inches of many species in shallow water. 
Bleaching probably was due to a series of very low tides coupled with light winds and periods of heavy rain.

Extensive bleaching of the top 8 to10 inches of many species in shallow water. 
Bleaching probably was due to a series of very low tides coupled with light winds and periods of heavy rain.

In Jebel Ali all corals were bleached white, with only few individuals
( A. downingi recruits) partially bleached or unbleached.
Bleaching started during the last week of August when sea surface temperatures reached up to 37 degrees

Bleaching was more patchy and heaviest among
massive corals, less among Acropora.
No significant mortality was found yet, and recovery is still possible
properties.MORTALITY: Over 90% of bleached corals still had tissues and had not yet incurred even partial mortality

properties.NOTES: Observations at Kharabah Island (Most eastern Daymaniyat Island) made in late August showed that the most affected corals were in water less than 6m depth. The most severely affected species were Astreopora (100% of colonies totally bleached), Symphyllia
properties.SPECIES: Astreopora, Symphyllia recta, Goniopora sp.,  Platygyra and soft corals.

properties.NOTES: Coral belaching was fisrt observed in late July 1998, and by late August, bleachng had become extensive. Acroporid seems to be particularly susceptable to bleaching.
properties.DURATION: Start in July and coral dead in Sept.
properties.SPECIES: Acropora nobilis, A. cytherea, A. hyacinthus, A. digitifera

properties.RB_SOURCE: T. Kokita , A. Nakazon, 2001. Rapid response of an obligately corallivorous filefish Oxymonacanthus longirostris (Monacanthidae) to a mass coral bleaching event. Coral Reef Volume 20, Issue 2, pp 155-158.

properties.NOTES:
Pearl & Hermes; Midway; Kure. bleaching was most pronounced in backreef and reef flat habitats exposed to the most intense sunlight, warmest temperatures and strongest ultraviolet radiation.

properties.MORTALITY:
Towed diver surveys, which covered about 135 km of reef habitat (Pearl & Hermes; Midway; Kure Atoll)
at these three atolls, many areas were observed to have suffered greater 
than 50% coral mortality. Some areas had coral mortality close to 75%.

properties.NOTES: These corals are briefly exposed at low tide (new moon) when we experienced very high atmospheric temperatures coincident with  lack of trade winds.

Bleaching was observed at various spot within the bay.  The mushroom corals were the first to released its symbiont
algae, then some branching Acroporas and certain parts of massive coral heads.

Further bleaching in 2002 that killed many of the remaining non-massive corals. The massive corals also bleached, but
most recovered rapidly.
properties.MORTALITY: Further bleaching in 2002 that killed many of the remaining non-massive corals.
properties.RECOVERY: The massive corals also bleached, but most recovered rapidly.
properties.RB_SOURCE: Coral Bleaching and Mortality - the 1998 Event 4 Years Later and Bleaching to 2002. In: C.R. Wilkinson (ed.), Status of coral reefs of the world:2002. GCRMN Report, Australian Institute of Marine Science, Townsville. Chapter 1, pp 33-44

properties.NOTES: While most coral communities were recovering from the bleaching, another bleaching occurred from Ryukyu Islands to Amami Islands in summer 2001.
properties.MORTALITY: Higher mortality at 45.7-68.8% loss was evident in the southern Sekisei Lagoon and Ishigaki Island, southern Ryukyus, but there was no mortality in Miyako Islands and Amami Islands.
properties.RB_SOURCE: Dai, et al. 2002.  Status of Coral Reefs in East and North Asia: China, Korea, Japan and Taiwan. In: C.R. Wilkinson (ed.), Status of coral reefs of the world:2002.

properties.NOTES: All coral species seems to be affected, mostly in shallow waters, but also at depth up to 8m. It seems that water temperature has begun to drop down for now on.

Some of the corals were showing signs of stress.  Colonies of Millepora complanata were bleached .... with colonies ranging from fully bleached-out to colonies that were partially bleached.  While none of the other species of corals were fully bleached,

Reef Relief's Craig Quirolo has observed extensive paling on Diploria strigosa in the Noname Cay Abacos, Bahamas on July 13.

properties.NOTES:
The stony corals have nearly all become stressed. They are white or 'dayglow' yellow or 'dayglow' orange. At least 90% of nearly all stony corals are affected. The various species called "Cactus" corals are showing stress.

We just finished four days of disease surveys and there is no bleaching. Few colonies of Palythoa, deep Agaricia, Eusmilia fastigiata and one Colpophyllia natans showed paling. Everything looks normal and water temperature are also normal.

I have just returned from 2 weeks in Bonaire and we saw very little bleaching in Bonaire. A few Eusmillia fastigiata, but not very many and no complete colony bleaching.
Water temperatures were around 28 C, cooler than the usual mid-September

We have just returned from Tobago where we have been conducting our 
CARICOMP monitoring, and we have observed bleaching of most of the hard 
corals on Buccoo Reef.

properties.LOCATION: Gulf Stream Reef Boynton Beach, Florida
properties.NOTES: Meandrina meandrites colonies on Gulf Stream Reef Boynton Beach, Florida have been observed to bleach and recover on a predictable annual cycle. Six years of observation (2000 to 2005) has documented this occurrence. The annual onset of bleaching begins
properties.RB_SOURCE: Maze Coral  Meandrina meandrites)  Autumnal Bleaching Cycle Gulf Stream Reef, Boynton Beach, Florida website. http://hometown.aol.com/etichscuba/page1.html

properties.NOTES:
In early October 2006 on Majuro atoll (RMI), shallow coral bleaching was detected (the first episode since last February), restricted to low-tide exposed colonies (mainly Acropora, zooanthids) Very low mortality, so far.
More interesting, in mid-
properties.MORTALITY: Very low mortality
properties.RB_SOURCE: Dean Jacobson [atolldino@yahoo.com] in Coral list on 28/10/2006

properties.NOTES: Saw bleaching of Pocillopora verrucosa on the reef crest (1m or less) at Anae Island, Agat, Guam.
properties.RB_SOURCE: Lisa Chau [sirendipity009@yahoo.com] in Coral list on 19/9/2006

properties.NOTES: Rob Rowan, reported seeing bleaching on the reef crest (1-2m) at Pago Bay (right off the marine lab), Guam.
properties.RB_SOURCE: Lisa Chau [sirendipity009@yahoo.com] in Coral list on 19/9/2006

properties.NOTES:
Date of observation: June - November 2005
Depth of Area bleached: 0 - 42 meters
Reef zone: reef flat and -slope
Percentage of live coral cover in the area: 19%
Coral Species affected:
Diplorea strigosa, Colpohylia natans: 100
properties.SPECIES:
Diplorea strigosa, Colpohylia natans Montastraea annularis, 
Stephanocoenia intersepts, Montastraea cavermosa, Siderastrea sidera, Madracis mirabilis, Madracis formosa, Acropora palmata, Sea Plumes- Pseudopterogorgia spp., Common Sea Fan- Gorgonia venta
properties.RB_SOURCE:
Kai Wulf (kai_wulf@mac.com), Soufriere Marine Management Association Inc.
Personal communication to reefbase (2/4/2006)

properties.NOTES: Partial bleaching of corals and the presence of filamentous algae also affected the corals. There were 11 corals that were found entirely bleached.

properties.RB_SOURCE: Hoffmann, T.C. 2002. Coral reef health and effects of socio-economic factors in Fiji and Cook Islands. Marine Pollution Bulletin, Volume 44, Issue 11: 1281-1293 pp

properties.NOTES: Site number 6 have 22 bleached corals among the 5 sampled sites. There were altogether 30 bleached corals found in all sites.
